description.text: I kept losing my guitar picks.  Needed a place for them to rest.  Just got a new 3D printer, so I mocked up something quick.

This thing was made with Tinkercad: https://www.tinkercad.com/things/kjkwal8UzEc You need two of these (top and bottom) to sandwich eight pairs of 18650 batteries.Then you can slot them together to create larger battery packs. I've been re-using recycled laptop batteries for an electric lawn mower, electric go-cart and electric drill. Next step is a DYI "Tesla style" power wall with several thousand 18650 cells.

This is the first Amazon Dash accessory to be made available on Thingiverse - or at least the first one to be appropriately tagged as such.
The idea here is that when you get a new bundle of paper towel rolls, you jam the Bounty Buddy into one of the rolls designating it as the 'last roll'.  When you finally get to the last roll you hit the button and a drone delivers you new paper towels, or a UPS driver depending on where you live and what decade you're living in.
The shroud protects the button from accidental orders, but is not necessary.

This is a printable Hexapod. It is still not very stable and still learning to walk, but it is a good start. It needs some changes in the leg design as sometimes they bend under the weight.
The initial design is based on :
http://robozone.su/forum/textversion.html?t58 The changes I have done are the additions described below and also decrease the size of the Body plates to fit a standard Mendel. And I am currently using this software to control it: http://www.hexapodrobot.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=25&t=160 Be aware that the hexapod is still not very stable (legs bending) and that is why it is work in progress.

Print Body_Up and Body_down for the body. You will need the basic:
6x Fuss
6x Bein
6x Moto1
3x Moto2
3x Moto3 ( this is the same as Moto2, but in the other direction) Addition:
bracket1-3 are additions for Bein. It makes the leg moer stable and does not bend. You will need also Bein2. Check the legs on the picture. You will need 18 servo machines. The legs are being gathered with M3 bolts and M3 rods.

comments.text: Very nice hexapod kit!   Yes the fuse part of the legs do bend a bit but there is an easy fix!  Just print out two for ever leg and put one on each side of the servo  and a spacer at the foot with a bolt attaching the two when go to mount it!  After that seems to be rock solid and does not flex much now.  I printed everything with 40% infill .02 layers as well if helps anyone trying to build this!  I plan on posting few photos shortly when I get my digital camera back lent to friend.  Also the round servo horns come with the tower power MG 995 servos fit the inlays on arms and body perfectly for a nicer look, Then normal 1 inch arms shown everyone using!

title: 29mm fin can for Estes BT-56 body tube.

description.text:
This is a replacement fin can for the Estes Eliminator rocket, and will probably work for other purposes.  It fits on an existing BT-56, and with sanding or fiddling, on a BT-55.  It should be stable for all mid-power 29mm motors.  
The picture with the fins attached to the unfinished rocket must viewed with "large view" to be viewed seen.  Otherwise it's just a purple tube.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes: Set to a single shell for best results. 2 shells have caused fins to separate internally, reason unknown. PLA in particular could deform when hot. Sanding out the interior a bit and coating with epoxy could prevent this. My final versions will be printed in ABS. Future enhancements will allow for better performance at trans-sonic velocities.

title: Laser Mount for Printrbot Simple Metal

description.text: Here is a laser mount for a 2.5W Blue Laser (445nm) that I bought on sale for less than $100 on banggood.com. It mounts beside the extruder using existing screws, with no modifications required on the Printrbot. Video of the laser in action is at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_1ZuSHSmTE4

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3 mm

Infill:

100%

Using the laser Mount the laser with a couple of M3x8mm screws. Note that the laser I used runs continuously and does not allow for on/off control. For engraving, I created a Cura profile that eliminates Z homing, eliminates extruder and bed temperature settings, and disables retraction. Non-printing moves are as fast as possible, while printing moves are at whatever speed gives you the engraving depth you want. The engraving shown was created from thing#1057499 (hat tip to SMooreArtDesign). I placed the object upside down so that the top layer was on the bottom. Print speed was 5mm/s. After slicing, I edited the gcode to eliminate all but the first layer. I started the print and plugged in the laser. As soon as the head stopped moving at the end of the print, the laser was unplugged to keep from burning in one spot.
Safety Of course, ALWAYS use eye protection when using a laser this powerful. The laser is powerful enough to blind you instantly.

author: tedkeys

description.text: From Destiny. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=riD10vjNOk0

A derivation of the Estes Swift 220, this uses an 18mm engine with a fin-integrated launch lug.   Easy to lose on larger engines.  Print in bright colors for best chance of finding it.  See printing details for assembly and flight.  This version has somewhat better stability and fin size compared to my first version, though the first one did fly straight on a C6-5.  Do NOT fly on powerful composite motors as fin flutter will break the fins off.  Stick to black powder or equivalent.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100% and 20%

Notes: For the rocket body, set infill shells to 1 or the fins have the potential to really mess up. Initial attempts left shells at the default 2 and pieces of the fin didn't even print. They tended to split in two. Not good. Also, the nose prints separate. The nose should be glued or welded into the main rocket. The engine blows free and the resulting pieces are light enough that they do not fall at a dangerous speed -- called tumble recovery. Use 100% infill on the rocket body. 40%-50% fill should be fine for the nose. You can generally get away with less fill, but the extra weight does help. The rocket benefits from rafts, the nose can be printed with the flat bottom on the tray. Note that both the original and this version were originally designed by me, but Jay did the OpenSCAD coding and first print of it. This derivative has better stability for all engines. The original flew fine in tests, but there was some uncertainty if that extended to all standard sized 18mm engines. This should work with just about anything.

description.text:
Pose-able Minecraft action figure that actually works. If print settings are correct the accessories should snap into place. Mirror the arm to make the left arm. no supports needed.
Let me know if you like it! or if you think something could be better.

Christmas is rapidly approaching .... well approaching fast enough for my wife to say "Now you can put that 3D printer to some good use making christmas decorations". (Sigh). So inspired by the house design at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:610696 I decided to try to make a little christmas village from different style houses. This is my first design in OpenScad. It has trees and stars and even Santa! There are two holes in the bottom for LEDs. It's small, so that much of the detail gets lost using a 0.4mm nozzle. But it's designed to the printed easily in PLA or ABS with no supports and a minimum of bridging.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm / layer

Infill:

10%

Notes: OpenScad complains that it may not be a valid 2 manifold. But Slic3r isn't worried by it. I'll have to spend some time finding out where the problem is - later. Should print easily with no supports.

So my wife says "The trees should be green".
I say - "But they are covered in snow".
She says "Really - in Australia! Go get the paint".
(Sigh).

title: V-tail Frame for the Hubsan X4 Quadcopter

description.text:
V-Tail quad-copter frame using the Hubsan X4 board. All motors were upgraded to 8.5mm coreless motors. It has a very sharp and responsive Yaw control. Stock props can provide enough lift but only at 80% throttle. Exchanging the back stock props with bigger ones will improve the performance. My current setup is listed below:
  • Front prop: Stock props
  • Back prop: YD717 props
  • Board mounts from the bottom of the frame
  • Back motor wires may need to be extended to reach the board
    • Additional Information:
  • Tilted (dihedral) front motors: 5° to the center
  • Front wing angle: 150°
  • V-tail angle: 120°

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

30%

Notes: PET+ works the best for it's durability and can survive the most intense crashes. ABS and PLA can work but can't survive that many crashes V-tail legs need to be printed separately and glued to the bottom of the frame.

description.text: The Modular e-NABLE Tool Adapter allows you to equip customized tool attachments to a Raptor Reloaded or Phoenix hand. Scaling up with either hand model (left or right), it uses a slider to lock a tool in place. Attachments are designed to be customize-able and allow for a wide range of creative possibilities provided that they use the same octagonal base. Included with the adapter files are a 13/16 inch broom holder attachment at 100% scale and 140% scale as well as the attachment base for creating your own attachments (currently only in .stl but can be recreated in other formats). I'm considering overhauling the design by recreating the adapter in multiple 5% scales using the same size tool attachment base to help streamline the attachment design process. This is a very preliminary design and there are many additions and changes expected in the coming weeks. If you use this design and create new attachments please share them so we can create a library for different tools! Don't have a Raptor Reloaded? Print your own with these files from Thingiverse: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:596966 Check out e-NABLE on Google+: https://plus.google.com/communities/102497715636887179986

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3 or Finer

Infill:

20% for Tool Adapter, 40% for Slide Lock

Notes: Using PLA use standard print settings and the below recommendations for each part. I have not tested ABS, let me know if you do! You will need a strip of velcro and some sanding tools or files to finish this. Tool Adapter: From my experience using Cura as slicer I have had the best results printing the tool adapter as oriented in it's .stl file with supports everywhere and a raft. The raft may not be necessary depending on how well your prints stick to your print bed but if you don't mind the extra filament used it seems a safer bet. 20% infill seems to work well, you can increase it but keep in mind it will also increase the weight. Slide Lock: Print as oriented in the .stl file with supports everywhere. I like to increase the infill to 40% for this part as the snaps that lock the tool in place will be the most likely part to break in the course of use. I'd also recommend going with at least a 0.2 resolution with this part. Attachment print settings will depend on the tool but I would suggest at least a 40% infill for greater durability. After printing remove all supports and sand or file away any rough edges. Attachments especially need sanding or to be worked in repeatedly to fit well. Cut a strip of Velcro a little over the length of the hand to secure the adapter in place under the palm of your printed hand.

description.text:
This example is based on the following resources:

http://blog.makezine.com/archive/2010/06/make-your-own-gears.html
http://repraprip.blogspot.com/2011/05/inkscape-to-openscad-dxf-tutorial.html
http://www.iheartrobotics.com/search/label/OpenSCAD



Gear basics
If you know any two things about gearsâ€”outer diameter and number of teethâ€”you can use some simple equations to find everything else you need to know, including the correct center distance between them.
Number of Teeth (N)
How many teeth are there in the gear

Pitch Diameter (D):
The circle on which two gears effectively mesh, about halfway through the tooth. The pitch diameters of two gears will be tangent when the centers are spaced correctly.

Diametral Pitch (P):
The number of teeth per inch of the circumference of the pitch diameter. Think of it as the density of teethâ€”the higher the number, the smaller and more closely spaced the teeth on a gear. Common diametral pitches for hobby-size projects are 24, 32, and 48. The diametral pitch of all meshing gears must be the same.

Circular Pitch (p) = pi / P:
The length of the arc between the center of one tooth and the center of a tooth next to it. This is just pi (Ã¯â‚¬ = 3.14) divided by the diametral pitch (P). Although rarely used to identify off the shelf gears, you may need this parameter when modeling gears in 2D and 3D software like we're doing here. As with diametral pitch, the circular pitch of all meshing gears must be the same.

Outside Diameter (Do):
The biggest circle that touches the edges of the gear teeth. You can measure this using a caliper like Sparkfun.com's # TOL-00067.

Note: Gears with an even number of teeth are easiest to measure, since each tooth has another tooth directly across the gear. On a gear with an odd number of teeth, if you draw a line from the center of one tooth straight through the center across the gear, the line will fall between two teeth. So, just be careful using outside diameter in your calculations if you estimated it from a gear with an odd number of teeth.

Center Distance (C):
Half the pitch diameter of the first gear plus half the pitch diameter of the second gear will equal the correct center distance. This spacing is critical for creating smooth running gears.

Pressure Angle:
The angle between the line of action (how the contact point between gear teeth travels as they rotate) and the line tangent to the pitch circle. Standard pressure angles are, for some reason, 14.5&Acir;Â° and 20Ã‚Â°. A pressure angle of 20Ã‚Â° is better for small gears, but it doesn't make much difference. It's not important to understand this parameter, just to know that the pressure angle of all meshing gears must be the same.

Addendum:
how much the tooth protudes beyond the pitch radius

Dedendum:
how deep goes the tooth before any fillet take place

Pressure angle:
The angle between the radial direction and the tangent to the tooth at the pitch circle. 20 is a good value.

Some Rules

The value of the base circle is based on pressure angle.
  • 1.The smaller the pressure angle, the smaller the base radius
  • 2. The addendum must be less than the dedendum
  • 3. The dedendum must be more than the difference between the pitch and the base radius.



    • All of these gear parameters relate to each other with simple equations. To Get You Have Equation Diametrical Pitch(P)
    Number of teeth per unit length Circular Pitch(p)
    Number of Teeth(N) & Pitch Diameter(D)
    Number of Teeth(N) & Outside Diameter (Do) P=Ï€/p
    P=N/D
    P=(N+2)/Do(approx) Circular Pitch(p)
    Length of the arc from one tooth to the next Diametrical Pitch (P) p=Ï€/P Pitch Diameter(D) Number of Teeth(N) & Diametrical Pitch(P)
    Outside Diameter (Do) &Diametrical Pitch(P) D=N/P
    D=Do-2/P Number of Teeth(N) Diametrical Pitch(P) & Pitch Diameter(D) N=P*D Center Distance(CD) Pitch Diameter(D)
    Number of Teeth(N) & Diametrical Pitch(P) CD=(D1+D2)/2CD=(N1+N2)/2P

<br /> <br /> <ol><li>1. Open Inkscape (www.inkscape.org â€” free, open-source vector based drawing program ) and create a new document (CTRL+N).<br /><br /><hr /></li> <li>2. Under the file menu, go to Document Properties and change the default units in the upper right hand corner to inches (SHIFT+CTRL+D). This will change the rulers from pixels to inches. <br /><br /><hr /></li> <li>3. Create a gear: <span class="em">Extensions>Render>Gear</span>. <br /><br /><hr /></li> <li>4. The dialog box allows you to specify <ul><li>Number of Teeth</li> <li>Circular pitch, px</li> <li>Pressure angle</li> </ul> Leave Pressure angle alone â€” the 20Â° default is standard for off the shelf gears so is a good place to start. <br /><br /> Chose 28 teeth with a circular pitch of 24. Click Apply, then Close the dialog box, your gear should be displayed. <br /><br /><hr /></li> <li>5.<small>From Dustyn Roberts's Gear Tutorial</small><br /> <blockquote> Note on circular pitch: In Inkscape, the circular pitch is given in pixels, not inches, as we're used to using in the equations in the above table. You can get different gear ratios by just choosing a circular pitch that looks good and varying the teeth number, but if you want to make gears that interface with off the shelf gears, you need to pay a little bit more attention. By default in Inkscape there are 90 pixels in 1 inch. So if you set circular pitch to 24px in the gear tool as done above, that rounds to 0.267 inches (24/90 = 0.2666...).


Since diametral pitch (P) = Ï€/circular pitch (p), the diametral pitch (P) in inches is = Ï€/ 0.267 = 11.781. You will not find any off the shelf gears with a diametral pitch of 11.781. Common diametral pitches are 24, 32, and 48. So if you plan to make gears to play nice with off the shelf gears, start with the diametral pitch of your off the shelf gear and use the equations in the table to work backwards to what your circular pitch should be in pixels in Inkscape.

<li>6. There should be square and round handles on the object, which indicates it is an .svg object, which OpenSCAD can't read.<br /><br /><hr /></li> <li>7. You need to convert it to a path. [Shift+Ctrl+C]<br /><br /><hr /></li> <li>8. Select the node tool [N]. The handles on the object now look like gray squares. This indicates you have a path.

<li>10. Click "Make selected segment lines".


This looks much better. The lines are straight, but due to the sheer numbers, you see a curve!
Fit page to selection

<li>15.Open OpenSCAD <br /><br /><hr /></li> <li>16. Remember to put the .scad and .dxf file in the same directory).<br /><br /><hr /></li> <li>17. Here is the code <div class="codesample"><pre> linear_extrude(file = "something.dxf", height = 10, center = true);

<li>19. Add a cylinder in the center of the gear so that use can attach it to a base. You could make a 1/4" dowel (6.35mm). Or attach <a href="http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10541">Tony Buser's pin connector </a>to the end of your dower. In that case your radius will be 5.<br /> <br /><br /><hr /></li> <li>20. Compile and export<br /><br /><hr /></li> <li>21. Open the .stl in NetFabb and repair if necessary<br /><br /><hr /></li> <li>22. Open in ReplicatorG and print<br /><br /><hr /></li> <li>23. Since 1 gear will not do much for you, make at least one more. For your second gear select 14 teeth and keep the same pressure angle and circular pitch of the first gear so that your gears mesh - only change the number of teeth!<br /> <br /><br /><hr /></li>
  • Both of your gears have a circular pitch of 24 px, a pressure angle of 20Â°.
  • The big gear has 28 teeth and the small one has 14.
  • The circular pitch in pixels to a diametral pitch in inches of 11.781.
    • CD = (N1 + N2)/2P

title: Centered microswitch probe for classic Rostock 3-hole effector

description.text: This is a temporary microswitch probe that can be installed by simply clipping into place underneath one of the three M4 screws that the classic Rostock effector uses for mounting the hotend. It has only been tested against an E3Dv5 clone mounted using my lightweight 3-prong groove mount. The purpose of this mount is to hold a microswitch centered beneath the nozzle so that Smoothieware's G32 can do its job accurately. It is also parametric, so you can change the dimensions of the part for a different hotend or microswitch.

description.text:
This is a combination of the Ekobots 3mm Direct Drive extruder, my custom hot-end clamp system, and the fast-clamp library for k8200. 
The hotend clamp is designed to allow vertical adjustment of the hotend, to aid in levelling for dual extrusion. There is a mirrored version of both the extruder body and the idler.

Parts For a single extruder, it requires the following:
608ZZ bearing
MK8 drive gear
3x M3-10mm screws (motor)
3x M3-30mm screws (Idler + hotend clamp)
2x M4-40mm screws (idler tension + frame clip)
small spring for idler
appropriate nuts & washers.

description.text:
This image of various sized whistles:
http://www.thingiverse.com/derivative:680 got me thinking. Scaling is RIDICULOUSLY easy with Blender -- and then printing out the new part is just as easy as the previously sized part. So why not make a part that benefited from this scalability? So, I was thinking, there are all kinds of bottles out there. And adding a whistle to the top will basically form a resonance chamber of that bottle\'s note. Can anybody say Jug Band?

First, download the .stl, and scale it such that the plug diameter will fit your bottle. My spire mountain cider (in a standard beer bottle) needed a .7\" plug. 
Because the whistle prints best on its side, there will likely be some skuzziness on the plug surface, so you will probably have to cut or file that away.
Then, once it\'s printed, start tootin!

comments.text: I had much the same idea as this but, why not create a screw top replacement for a water bottle cap with a whistle on it, and then create a curved temple for tuning cutting tunning hole. Now, you and turn any Crystal Gyzer water bottle into a penny whistle. ah? ah?  Who's with me?

author: dmuren

description.text:
I had some heat issues with my (PLA) extruder and X-carriage, a M3 threaded rod melted through which I used to mount my hotend. I decided I needed some active cooling before I printed a new X-carriage and Extruder in ABS.
So I designed a simple mounting plate for a 4cm fan which bolts on to the bottom of the X-belt clamps.

• Get a 4cm fan (I used this one: http://www.dealextreme.com/p/cooling-fan-for-vga-video-display-card-4cm-4cm-15564)
  • Print the mounting plate
  • Drill some holes at the correct position to mount the fan to the plate (I suggest you use tie-wraps)
  • Secure the fan to the mounting plate
  • Bolt the mounting plate to the X-belt clamps (you might need longer bolts for them)
  • Hook up the fan to your electronics
  • Print with some active extruder cooling

comments.text: Do you have any 'Non-Plastic' between your hot end and the cold end plastic part of the extruder? Its hard to tell from your description or photos, and I only ask as I had a similar problem where I didn't.

description.text: I really wanted a way to carry just my phone and gym id and this does the trick.  It also has a little kickstand to let me prop it up on the dashboard to use GPS.

Print 1 copy each of all the parts except the sound button, you'll need two of those. After printing put the sound buttons in the bottom case. Then you'll take the mute switch and hold it in place while you slide the phone into the bottom case.
Then take the home button and put it in the top case and flip it upside down. Then you can take the bottom case and sandwich it onto the top case. Then I used 4 metric 18-8 SS Low Head Socket Cap Screw M3 Size, 6 mm Length, .5 mm pitch from McMaster-Carr (http://www.mcmaster.com/#catalog/119/3092/=na6il2) to hold the top onto the bottom.
Then I used a bamboo kabob skewer as the pin to hold the hinge of the credit card holder onto the bottom case. Anything with a 3.4 mm diameter should fit snugly in the hole.

Excellent design by sneakypoo. Thank you. My remix fits the Vertex K8400 without modifications and without extra hardware, except for one M3x12 screw/bolt. As the original, it allows you to use several sizes of spools. Since printers often print hole sizes too narrow, you probably need to resize the parts somewhat. Obviously, the ball bearings must fit inside the core, and the core threads must fit inside the nut threads. I resized the core part +3% in X and Y direction, and the nut part +5%, also in X and Y direction. The Z direction size changes must be the same in both parts, or the threads will bite and lock one another. I left Z sizes unchanged. These are my figures. Your printer might be better tuned than mine. Make test prints, 10 mm high or so, and check that the parts fits not too tight not too loose, before you start the full 5 hour print. I wish I had done so. The supplied stl files are not resized. The screw keeps the core in place. A tooth pick and a small glue blob will probably also work.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10-15%

Notes: Print the core part "mushroom style", the pointy end downwards, there is one small horizontal surface inside. You might get away with printing it other end up, have not tried that. As it is, it definitely needs a brim, I used a 10 mm one.

comments.text:
For me +3 % for was to big. No change to small. I guess +2% could be enough, maybe also +1 %.
There 2 horizontal holes in the screw. One is big enough for the M3 x 12 screws which comes with the Vertex assembly kit. But for what it the other hole? It is a little bit to small for thes M3 screws.

One of the hardest parts of designing the pipe organs (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1037991 & http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1051888) was getting the pipes to work. I found the equations on http://www.rwgiangiulio.com/ extremely helpful but this still required modelling each pipe individually. I have now come up with this parametric version to make it simple to make different sized pipes by just entering the variables. Hope you enjoy!

comments.text: By the way, as far as my experience with wooden pipes goes, a TIP: Open pipes are easier to make functional than closed ones. So if someone else wants to try this customizer, start with an open one. It will play one octave higher though.

With a printed item you can scrape a bit with a knife, but if you go too far then your can throw out the complete pipe.. Maybe an idea for a next version to make the critical parts finetuneable (after printing that is) ;)

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a remix I've made and tested on a Prusa i2. I've done lots of reworks from the original source (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:887386). Improvements:
-MK7 drive gear support!
-It is now adapted for Prusa i2 x-carriage
-Remodelled lever. Now uses the standard 623 bearings!
-Pressure system is new making it similar to other Prusa i2
-Hotend now fits perfectly and you're able to install a fan in the hotend without tocuhing x-carriage
-Screw holes have been adjusted and added to fit motor I use the bowden thing and then a 3mm thick teflon tube to guide filament from the bearing and motor all the way to the extruder. This is recommended for flexible filaments. Fan I used: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:94086 Printing speeds are higher than 70mm/s with a 0.4mm nozzle using PLA!
Flexible filaments are compatible. Printing speeds higher than 40mm/s!

I needed extra height under the printer to my PSU, so this gives approx. 25mm :)

This is a platform frame for the Custom MK3 Alu heatbed 240x214mm that Marlark aka Me ;) provide mainly for the Vertex K8400 owners. If you want to buy a heatbed you can email me on [email protected] or visit the forum thread http://forum.velleman.eu/viewtopic.php?f=64&t=14714 for further information. I printed the frame in ABS but can be made in other heat tolerable filament types. What this construct does is it move the build platform backward and extends it. The idea is to make clearance and to be able to use this fully you need a new glass plate 240x240mm. You also need 2 neodyne magnets pref a diameter around 10mm x 2,5mm. Reason for me making the glass bigger is im planning on trying to extend the build area on the Y axis (magicly remove some of the space the front fan use) and i needed some of the size for the magnet lock.. Want to thank @Svdv for beeing my inspiration for this project and my wife for putting up with the ABS vapor fumes ;)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,21 mm

Infill:

50%

Notes: For the FArm you might need a Raft and slow down the printspeed due to most of it might need to be printed on supports. PS ..... A little tricky that part.

Instructions Glue a magnet in the hole of the underside of the FArm. and one on the underside of the glass plate. Use 2 M3 screws and locking nuts to put the RightB and LeftB on the FArm. Reuse the old original Screws/Bolts and you can ether use 3 solutions with wing nuts or the original nuts or even with springs and one of the 2 first options. Totally up to the user there ;) Finally put in the heatbed and the glass plate ontop.

1pcs bolt M3x6mm (countersunk flat head);
12mm shaft ø5mm for ball bearing;
Spring ø7.5 x 8.1-15mm. My from dryer clips (Ikea PRESSA series);
Short PTFE tube ø4mm under the gear as a filament guide.

title: Xiaomi 10000 mAh powerbank case for Xiaomi Yi, GoPro and similar cameras

description.text: More about this project: http://vedranpapes.from.hr/essays/2015/10/m3d-3d-printing-project-xiaomi-10000-mah-powerbank-case-for-xiaomi-yi-gopro-and-similar-action-cameras/

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

MID to HIGH

Infill:

FULL

Notes: As I've printed it on M3D settings are kind of different compared to other 3D printers.
But, I've printed it with some cheap PLA at 210C.
Set resolution to MID and infill to FULL.
M3D software said that it would print for 29h but it printed for more then 48h :D

Step 1. Clean supports Step 2. find M5 screws and nuts Step 3. As nut size isn't good in casing you need to melt that part Use pliers to keep nut and get it really hot so that you can stick it in case nut compartment.
Use epoxy and glue it. Step 4. Use Plasti Dip Spray the whole casing with Plasti Dip.
First It'll make casing sturdier and more grippy. Second, it'll make GoPro clips slide easier.
I've only sprayed one layer on clips and mounts. And 4 layers to the rest of the casing. Step 5. Use 1,5cm M5 screws to screw cover to the case Step 6. You can Plasti Dip the cover as you wish Step 7. Add velcro straps As my case have velcro holes, you can easily strap this case to your bag or anywhere else :) Step 8. Enjoy :) Create your own covers, remix, edit whatever you want with this case and share it :)
I'd like to see your ideas too! :) Check my post about this project:
http://vedranpapes.from.hr/essays/2015/10/m3d-3d-printing-project-xiaomi-10000-mah-powerbank-case-for-xiaomi-yi-gopro-and-similar-action-cameras/

Without Thingiverse it would be really hard! More about how I designed it you can read here:
http://vedranpapes.from.hr/essays/2015/10/m3d-3d-printing-project-xiaomi-10000-mah-powerbank-case-for-xiaomi-yi-gopro-and-similar-action-cameras/ But I've used Tinkercad for most of designing. Thanks to great design of grips from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:719230 by Thumber that I used for my case.

A recreation of the M40 grenade used by the Colonial Marines in Aliens.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Notes: The top section needs to be printed with supports because of the overhangs. The rest should be fine. I suggest you print in the orientation the parts are supplied. Infill and resolution at your discretion.

Finishing I did the usual sanding and filling until the print was smooth, then sprayed the piece up with Plasticote Chrome. The small primer on the base should be gold. The cap can be either be printed in red or green, or painted the right colour afterwards. It needs a white stripe adding, which I did by masking the cap with tape and giving it a light coat of white spray. You can glue the button in place, or you can use the spring from an old biro to allow the button to move.

This is a simple clip to mount a Kanex HDMI to VGA adapter to a wall or ceiling.  I used it to mount the adapter to the ceiling, near a projector (to run Apple TV). The screw holes were designed for #6 counter sunk machine screws, though #8 seemed to fit too. The screw holes are about 28mm apart on center (designed to fit the existing holes for a two gang box in the ceiling tile).    It was cheaper than buying an HDMI projector...

Measured the Kanex, used Google SketchUp (2014, Licensed).

title: Samsung Galaxy S phone skateboard mount

description.text: This is a simple mount to attach a mobile phone to a skateboard to record movies. It is made to match the shape of a Samsung Galaxy S but may be modified to fit other phones easily. The mount is split in two pieces which makes it easy to print and also allows to easily detach the phone from the skateboard when not in use without having to unscrew anything. The bottom piece is meant to be screwed to the board. The holes are made to match the existing holes in the board used to hold the wheels, some boards (specially longboards) have spare holes so you can change the distance between the wheels. These spare holes can be used to hold the bottom piece. If you don't have spare holes you might need to make them :-(. The union between the two pieces is based on friction and there's 1mm of gap between the hole and the peg, depending on your printing results you may need to adjust this so that they hold tightly. Note this is meant to take movies while cruising and going around in a calm way, this is not meant for tricks, please don't blame me if you use this and you run over your phone!! UPDATE: I made an enhanced version with a leg and a slightly bigger bracket to hold the phone with a rubber cover. The model name for this version is "grapaFUNDA". UPDATE #2: Here comes a lame video I recorded using this: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qzGVhhiwzAs
Print, screw the bottom piece to some spare holes in your board (if you have them), put the phone in place and go ride.

comments.text: If the mount was readjustable, it could be used for more phones

comments.text: I've just uploaded the original FreeCAD file that I used to build this model. Looking at the Makerbot software - and I haven't used it to be clear - it sounds like you might be able to use it to change scale and other basic functionality, but it may be worth considering other modelling software. Consider 123D Design by Autodesk for a more gradual introduction to design or, if you're feeling brave - FreeCAD. It has a slightly steeper learning curve, but is very capable once you get a feel for it. Both are free, so nothing lost. Good luck.

remixed_from.title: NCS Rumba mount for Prusa i3 steel

title: NCS Raspberry Rumba mount for Prusa i3 steel

description.text:
• Mount uses standard mount holes on i3 Steel printers
  • Mount both Rumba board and Raspberry Pi on same bracket
  • use standard Raspberry Pi case to mount to bracket
  • use 2 3mm screws for mount pins up to 12mm in length
  • added optional spacers 9mm tall for smaller printers where clearance is an issue
  • added the ability to use the Vilros Case
    1 https://www.vilros.com/shop/raspberry-pi/raspberry-pi-3-clear-case/
    2 also comes as a kit at amazon https://www.amazon.com/s/ref=nb_sb_noss?url=search-alias%3Delectronics&field-keywords=B01D92SSX6
  • download latest file

This is a replacement legs for a pair of sunglasses that i own.
After printing this model, i took it to a local glasses shop to get them custom fitted.
(the person used a heating machine to soften the PLA and bend them slightly to fit my head's curve. So if you have a skill and a heat gun, i guess you could do it by yourself.)
the stiffness of the joint was just perfect, the tolerance was just at the perfect point where the legs would connect to the glasses just right without the use of any adhesive

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm Layer Height

Infill:

15%

Notes: This model is only compatible to specific type of sunglasses, so make sure you check before you print it for yourself. You may have to adjust the length of the leg to work with your specific glasses, you are free to edit the 123dx file that i've attached It's better to print them up side down, as it required less support material and gives a much more smoother feeling when you actually wear them. I recommend taking it to a local glasses shop to customize the curvature for your head

No

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

25%

Notes: easy and fast to print, less than 20 minutes

This is a simple little 1 inch test cube that I designed to test out different filaments.  It has a different sized hole going through each plane so you can learn how your printer skews dimensions based on the axis.  For instance, my printer is extremely accurate (+-.005" or better) in the z-axis.  But it tends to shrink holes slightly when they are printed in the x-plane.
